texts.shortText:
Colony consists of a flat, white, lacelike sheet growing on flat-bladed algae, especially the red alga Rhodymenia obtusa.

Examined closely the individual zooecia are hexagonal, with a pair of rounded tubercles on each of the distal corners. Zooids with 15 transparent white tentacles.
Individual zooecia less than 1 mm long, colonies typically about 10 cm long.

Global: Widely distributed across subtropical and temperate seas including north and south Atlantic and Indo-Pacific. Probably a species complex with unresolved different species in different regions.

Local/Regional: Atlantic coast only.
Commonly found on the blades of red algae, especially Rhodymenia obtusa. Also occur on drift algae in the open ocean and may be distributed that way. Few other details available.

All bryozoans are filter-feeders. The feeding zooids extend when undisturbed and the tentacles, which are lined with cilia, are expanded, forming a bell-shaped funnel. Beating of the cilia directs food particles down into the funnel and to the mouth, where they are ingested.
Hermaphrodite. Colonies expand by budding new zooecia along the margins. New colonies arise from sexual reproduction and settlement of planktonic larvae at new sites but details unknown.

Easily confused with the Rustic lace animal Membranipora rustica, which also forms flat white growths on large, flat-bladed algae. The zooecia of that species are elongate and rectangular though and lack tubercles on the corners. The Hairy lace animal, Electra pilosa, also makes white sheets on algae, but zooecia are elongate triangular with one long and four short spines along margin of orifice.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 136).

Day, JH (1969). A Guide to marine Life on South African Shores. AA Balkema, Cape Town. (p. 129).

Florence, WK, Hayward, PJ & Gibbons, MJ (2007). Taxonomy of shallow-water Bryozoa from the west coast of South Africa. African Natural History, 3(1), 1-58. (p. 10).

Taylor, PD & Monks, N (1997). A new cheilostome bryozoan genus pseudoplanktonic on molluscs and algae. Invertebrate biology, 39-51.
